body: Joyce Maynard is the author of the novel ''Baby Love.'' New York has always been a city I come to from somewhere else. I lived there, very briefly - owned a good black suit and three silk blouses, rode the subway to work, bought my dinner at a deli every night on my way home and ate it in a Pullman kitchen overlooking Gramercy Park. But when I
title: A MOTHER INTRODUCES THE CITY

body: Glass fragments were found in two jars of Gerber's baby food last night by a Brooklyn couple whose 11-month-old daughter had been fed half of one jar, according to the police. The child was taken to St. John's Episcopal Hospital where doctors said she seemed to be unaffected. Last Friday the Gerber Products Company of Fremont, Mich., recalled
title: A Couple Finds Glass In Child's Baby Food

body: The New York City Department of Health cited 11 food establishments last week for violating the health code. In addition, it named five that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and one that was closed for having failed to do so. The establishments are these: VIOLATIONS Ruslan Inc., 1067 Madison Ave. T-A Gleason's Tavern on
title: 11 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code

body: Officials were trying to determine yesterday how a few seconds of pornography flashed onto the screen in the middle of a Laurel and Hardy film being shown at a Brooklyn elementary school. ''The parents are as angry as we are,'' said Sidney Aronson, principal of the school, Public School 203, in the Flatlands section. ''They're terribly upset and
title: THE CITY ; ; Obscenity Spliced IntoFilmatSchool

body: In the autumn of 1982 a wing at the Diplomat Hotel near Times Square was being remodeled into a discoth eque that was to be named the Cowboy Palace. The discoth eque never opened, but Federal officials said an undercover investigation that began at the Cowboy Palace led to the smashing of a major organized-crime loan-sharking ring that at its peak
title: LOAN-SHARKING INQUIRY GIVES OFFICIALS NEW INSIGHTS INTO ORGANIZED CRIME

body: The Department of Health cited 24 food establishments last week for violating the city's health code. In addition, it named five that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for having failed to do so. title: 24 Food Outlets Cited by City

body: A driver who was indicted for manslaughter after his concrete-mixer truck crashed into a parked car and killed a woman and her two children last year in Manhattan has been permitted to plead guilty to reduced charges with a promise of no prison term. The plea was accepted by Acting Justice Luis M. Neco of State Supreme Court after another acting
title: JUDGE ACCEPTS REDUCED PLEA IN FATAL CRASH

body: Thirteen men were indicted yesterday on charges of having refused to give testimony or having evaded questions before a Manhattan grand jury investigating a major loan-sharking and extortion ring. Among the indicted were several reputed organized-crime figures, including Joseph Yacovelli, who has been identified as a leader of the Colombo crime
title: 13 INDICTED AFTER INVESTIGATION OF MAJOR LOAN-SHARKING RING

body: The body of a city marshal missing since last Tuesday when he was serving eviction papers was found in a garbage-strewn lot in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the police said. A police spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, said the body had been found in weeds at the foot of Flatlands Avenue, off Autumn Avenue. It bore the
title: MISSING MARSHAL FOUND DEAD

body: THE streets of Canarsie help tell the story of a community older than the nation itself. On a few blocks in this section of southeastern Brooklyn, the slope from sidewalk to front door discloses the original terrain of a neighborhood that once survived on farming and fishing. Not until modern sewers were installed less than 40 years ago were street
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: CANARSIE
